title: S&P 500 Weekly Update: Across-The-Board Highs - Don't Try To Outthink This Bull Market
text: Housing continues its powerful recovery, while many still talk of a double-dip recession ahead. Global economic data continues to suggest the slow rebound remains on track despite more lockdowns.

title: Weekly High Frequency Indicators: All Time Frames Remain Positive; Pandemic And Policy Responses Still Determinative
text: High frequency indicators can give us a nearly up-to-the-moment view of the economy. The metrics are divided into long-leading, short-leading, and coincident indicators.

title: The Market Has Seen Big Gains in 2020. Next Year Will Bring New Surprises.
text: The biggest mistake investors may be making is looking at the past decade and extrapolating into the future. We won't make the same mistakes this time.

title: Wall Street Looks Ready to Meet a Pent-Up Demand for Deal Making
text: M&A and investor activism were suppressed for much of 2020. But plenty of money in SPACs, a hot IPO market, and abundant private-equity dry powder could lead to a very big year for deals.

title: The S&P 500 Could Gain Another 10% Next Year
text: Even as the market hits new highs, our experts see room for stocks to rise as Covid is vanquished and the economy reopens.

title: Expect Rocky Several Months for Markets: Laura Tyson
text: Dec.18 -- Laura Tyson, distinguished professor at the Haas School of Business at U-C Berkeley and RockCreek senior adviser, expects a rocky several months for markets followed by a strong recovery. The former chair of the Council of Economic Advisers during the Clinton administration also says the stock market is much stronger than the real economy.

title: Cramer's game plan for the trading week of Dec. 21
text: "Once the index funds finish selling everything else to make room for [Tesla], I'm betting the Santa Claus rally resumes," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: What it takes to join the Nasdaq and how it is different than joining the S&P
text: Nasdaq Executive Vice President Lauren Dillard discusses the new companies that have joined the Nasdaq in 2020. text: The Fed's emergency lending authorities are a key part of its job. Republicans want to curb them.

text: Chairman, Co-CEO & Chief Investment Officer and Lead Portfolio Manager at Ariel Investments John W. Rogers, Jr. weighs in on the stock market, valuations, and what investors should look out for in 2021.

title: Federal Shutdown On Horizon As Congress Stalls On Stimulus Talks
text: Capitol Hill lawmakers prepared to settle in for a working weekend in a bid to pass a COVID-19 stimulus bill – and with it, the funding necessary to keep the federal government operating. The federal government technically runs out of money at midnight on Friday.

title: US Indexes End Lower Friday With Gains for the Week
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 30,179.05 on Friday with a loss of 124.32 points or -0.41%. The S&P 500 closed at 3,709.41 for a loss of 13.07 points or -0.35%.

title: Should ETF Investors Be Worried about the Delisting of Chinese Equities?
text: By Liqian Ren, Director of Modern Alpha, WisdomTree On December 2, 2020, the House of Representatives voted to pass the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act, which passed the Senate in May. President Trump is expected to sign it into law.

title: Stock valuations elevated as warning signs rise
text: By Mark Hackett The equity market has been remarkably resilient since 2019 even with unprecedented disruption. The S&P 500® Index has returned more than 50% since January of last year despite the expectation for no earnings growth between 2019 and 2021.

title: The Dow Fell 124 Points. Blame Tesla and Congress.
text: The biggest gainer in the S&P 500 was Fortinet, up 6.9% as news about the SolarWinds cyberattack lifted shares of security companies.

title: Large Asset Managers Continue to Merge, With Bids for 2 Due Today
text: Both Bank of Montreal and Wells Fargo are expecting bids on Friday for their asset management businesses, according to people familiar with the situations.

title: Fed keeps countercyclical capital buffer at zero
text: The U.S. Federal Reserve Board voted Friday to keep its countercyclical capital buffer at zero percent, saying it would not order banks to hold additional capital to protect against losses in a future economic downturn.

title: Stock Market Today: Investors Lose Patience as Stimulus Talks Stretch On
text: Washington still hasn't hammered out a final COVID rescue bill, prompting investors to pull their foot off the pedal Friday.

title: 'Bloomberg Real Yield': The Lessons of 2020
text: Dec.18 -- Matt Hornbach, head of global macro strategy at Morgan Stanley, discusses the lessons of 2020, and his outlook for 2021. He speaks with Bloomberg's Jonathan Ferro on "Bloomberg Real Yield.

title: The Biggest Risk For Pre-Retirement And Retirement Investors Is The Wrong Asset Allocation
text: Traditional stocks and bonds have delivered very good returns the past decade, however the starting valuations today are very poor. The SPDR S&P 500 ETF averaged a 15.3% return on an average annual basis from 2009-2020, however, SPY only returned 1.2% on average annual basis from 2000-2010.

title: Fed's Clarida says current policy 'exactly where we want it'
text: (Reuters) -Federal Reserve Vice Chair Richard Clarida on Friday said further fiscal support would help get the economy through what he expects to be a "rough" next couple of months as coronavirus cases surge, but as for the U.S. central bank, policy is just where it should be.

title: This Markets Is Running on Fumes, Says Morgan Stanley
text: Dec.18 -- Morgan Stanley Wealth Management Chief Investment Officer Lisa Shalett says this market is running on fumes. She speaks with Bloomberg's Jonathan Ferro on "Bloomberg The Open.

title: US stocks fall from record highs as Congress nears deadline without stimulus agreement
text: US stocks fell from record highs on Friday as stimulus talks continued ahead of a key deadline.  Congress has just hours to finalize a new relief package before government funding lapses at midnight. If lawmakers can't reach a deal, they're set to pass a short-term funding bill for the second week in a row to continue stimulus talks into Christmas week. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell told reporters on Friday that he feels "more optimistic now" than he was last night, adding that a package "is very close at hand."

title: Dow ends lower but finishes off Friday's worst levels as lawmakers stumble toward coronavirus aid deal; Tesla officially in S&P 500
text: U.S. stock indexes on Friday pared declines into the close but finished lower in the last full week of trade in December as investors monitored last-minute negotiations toward cementing a coronavirus aid package amid worsening infections and hospitalizations due to COVID-19 pandemic. The day's trading action also was colored by a monstrous rebalancing of the S&P 500 and a quadruple-witching Friday that comes as Tesla was official gaining inclusion into one of the most exclusive clubs on Wall Street: The S&P 500.

title: Investors should expect volatility in markets, says Wells Fargo's Scott Wren
text: Scott Wren, from Wells Fargo Investment Institute, says investors will likely see volatility in the markets due to the upcoming Senate elections and stimulus negotiations. He joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss.

title: Federal Reserve vice chair: Don't think we'll have a double-dip recession
text: Richard Clarida, Federal Reserve vice chair, joins 'Closing Bell' to break down Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments at his news conference announcing the central bank's decision to leave interest rates unchanged.

title: High Volatility Will Last for Years: Man Group's Rattray
text: Dec.18 -- Man Group Plc's Chief Investment Officer Sandy Rattray says markets are likely to stay in a "higher volatility world" for multiple years and suggests designing investment strategies around that thesis. He speaks on "Bloomberg Markets: European Close.

title: Stimulus $900 billion deal continues to be held up, now it's over the Fed's lending power
text: #stimulus #FederalReserve #coronavirusstimulus Yahoo Finance's Brian Cheung reports on Senator Pat Toomey's (R-PA) latest demands on the stimulus deal that the Fed's lending power be limited. title: Yes, There Really Is A Santa Claus Rally
text: The stock market typically makes bigger-than-usual gains at the end of December and beginning of January. Here's why.

title: Ark's Wood Still Likes Tesla But Loves DNA Stocks More
text: Dec.18 -- Ark Investment Management's Cathie Wood explains why, in spite of her confidence in Tesla Inc., she thinks DNA stocks are likely to "surprise" as the biggest growth engines in her portfolios. Wood also discusses when she might invest in so-called FANG stocks.

title: A Little Less Concentration, A Little More Active
text: The U.S. stock market is concentrated like never before. This heavy concentration poses considerable downside risks for the S&P 500 Index going forward.

title: Stocks pull back after setting record highs

text: Democrats are criticizing GOP Sen. Pat Toomey in the hopes he will drop stipulations about the Fed's lending programs.

title: Barry Ritholtz and Josh Brown Won't Predict the Market, But They'll Talk About Anything Else.
text: The two financial advisors are known for their snappy, yet thoughtful, social-media presence. The duo sat down with Barron's for a longer conversation on how their business has evolved, new developments in index investing, and how they find time for it all.

title: The Fed: Move over black swans, the Fed's new worry are green swans
text: 'Green swans' unpredictable, highly disruptive events tied to climate change of the kind that blow up markets, are now on the Federal Reserve's list of worries, a top central banker said Friday.

title: Vaccine Rollout, Stimulus Talks Headline Wall Street's Big Week
text: The past five days marked a major step in the United States' fight against the pandemic, thanks to the initial rollout of Pfizer's (PFE) and BioNTech (BNTX) COVID-19 vaccine on Monday.

title: Expect Cyclical Rotation In Equities
text: We watched COVID-19 shut down the economy in March 2020 and saw U.S. equities collapse. The pandemic accelerated certain secular (long-term) trends, including digitalization, automation and e-commerce.

title: In One Chart: As the U.S. stock market surges in 2020, inequality has soared to a record high
text: As stocks staged a huge rebound from their lows in March, when the coronavirus pandemic threw the economy into recession, the gap between the wealthy and the poor extended a widening trend to historic proportions.

title: Baker Hughes data reveal a 4th straight weekly rise in the U.S. oil-rig count
text: Baker Hughes on Friday reported that the number of active U.S. rigs drilling for oil rose by 5 to 263 this week. That followed increases in each of the last three weeks.

title: El-Erian's Three Takeaways on the Markets From 2020
text: Dec.18 -- Mohamed El-Erian, president of Queens College, Cambridge, and a Bloomberg Opinion columnist, reflects on the turbulent year that was in markets and investing. He appears on "Bloomberg The Open.

title: Wall Street Week Ahead: Investors bet old-school retailers will rebound in 2021
text: As holiday shopping season wraps up, U.S. equity investors are gauging whether long-languishing shares of brick-and-mortar retailers can sustain their recent rebound in anticipation of a full economic reopening in 2021.

title: The Stock Market Has Already Devoured 2021's Promise. How to Stay Safe When Optimism Is Out of Control.
text: Surveys show rampant bullishness, born of the belief that vaccines will stifle Covid-19 and boost the markets. Some ways to play—and protect your portfolio against—the ebullience.

title: A Weak Dollar Is Good for the World: Steven Englander
text: Dec.18 -- Stephen Englander, global head of G10 FX research at Standard Chartered, says a weaker dollar is good for the world right now. He explains why on "Bloomberg The Open.
